newsitem.title: TAJIKISTAN: Red Cross resumes operations in Tajikistan.
newsitem.headline: Red Cross resumes operations in Tajikistan.

text.p: The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) said on Tuesday it had resumed operations in the former Soviet republic of Tajikistan.

Earlier this month, the ICRC and some other foreign aid organisations suspended activities in the country, devastated by a four-year civil war, after several of their employees were taken hostage by one of several armed factions.
Two of the hostages, including a British national, were employees with the ICRC.

"The ICRC has decided following the end of the recent hostage crisis to restart operations," Thomas Merkelbach, head of the ICRC delegation in Tajikistan, told a news conference in the capital Dushanbe.
However, Merkelbach said the ICRC could only operate if the country's various factions provided and honoured security guarantees for its workers.
"Only if we are really sure that our goods and people are respected by the different forces can we continue our activities," Merkelbach said.
A fragile peace has reigned in Tajikistan, which borders Afghanistan and China, since the government and the armed Islamist opposition agreed a ceasefire last December.
But the kidnappings by rogue guerrilla groups forced many foreign organisations to review their security, with several agencies yet to resume full operations in the republic.
